Main
Rules
Decision on business trip assignment
The decision to assign a business trip is made by C-Level Manager — Djivan M. and, in some cases, the team lead depending on the purpose of the trip. The assigned employee fills out and submits the request in the specified format to HR.
The employee submits the business trip request to HR for approval at least 7–10 business days before the planned trip date (excluding visa processing time if applicable).
HR coordinates the request with the direct manager and, if necessary, with C-Level Manager — Djivan M. Upon approval, HR sends the business trip instructions and the employee begins working independently with the Travel department (details below).
The HR responsible for receiving and processing business trip requests is Victoria Sedash, People Partner, Reddy 68139125607.
Please carefully review the Travel department's business trip rules when planning your trip.
A separate request must be filled out for each employee going on a trip.
Unapproved trips are monitored and may result in the trip cost being deducted from the employee's salary.

Types
of Business Trips
By type
External Event Any event or exhibition attended for business purposes for the team or Company, including brand awareness, client loyalty, expanding the client base, and establishing or maintaining business connections.
Business Trip A business trip to one of the subdivision offices — a trip with a business purpose, such as meetings, networking, strategic sessions, meetings with remote teams, and other activities that provide a business result for the employee, team, and/or subdivision.
By duration
Short-term Business trip duration up to 2 weeks.
Long-term Business trip duration more than 2 weeks.
Rules
for External
Events
and Exhibitions
1
Final approval of all business trips to external events and exhibitions is made by C-Level Manager — Djivan M.
2
Participation limit — no more than 4 employees from one team. This rule applies to any event trip.
3
Only the following teams can initiate participation in events:
  • Payment Expansion Dep. / MENA Subdiv;
  • Country Management / MENA Subdiv;
  • Mobicash / MENA Subdiv;
  • CIS/Global Subdiv;
  • Melbet MENA Subdiv;
  • China Dep.
Requests from other teams are considered only with separate approval from C-Level Manager — Djivan M.
4
Total participant limit per event — maximum 10 employees from all subdivision teams.
5
Even if each team provides 4 employees, the final composition (up to 10 people) is always determined by C-Level Manager — Djivan M.
Approval
Stages
Stage 1
Review is carried out within the employee's current position. If the offer included a salary change after the probation period, this change is not considered a review and is not included in the salary adjustment list.
Stage 2
The division manager evaluates their employees’ work (and their own if necessary) and determines the list of participants for review. If the employee’s position changes, they can be added to the general list only if approval of the change is required from the division manager.
Stage 3
The manager determines the new salary amounts according to the matrix, market salaries for similar positions, and the period since the previous review.
Stage 4
The manager prepares written justification for each employee’s review, including their own work (see Requirements for Justifications).
Working
with
Travel Department
1
After receiving the checklist from HR, the employee studies the business trip rules and independently fills out the Google form for the trip.
2
The Travel department receives the form and assigns a Travel Manager to work directly with the traveling employee.
3
In the trip form, you can specify all your wishes and trip details in the Comment section.
4
Before purchasing tickets (train, plane, bus, etc.) or booking accommodation, you can check available limits for the day via the Travel Department chat-bot (Reddy 72220000943).
5
The traveling employee can receive per diem before or after the trip. The employee requests the calculation of per diem through the Travel Manager.
6
Typically, per diem can be collected at the departure office from the office manager, senior office staff, or People Partner upon direct request from the traveling employee.
7
After receiving per diem information, the employee informs the responsible person for payment and receives the funds. Contact details for those responsible can be requested from HR (Victoria Sedash).
8
After confirming trip details, the employee informs the responsible HR about receiving the full set of documents from the Travel department.
9
Access transfer. For trips to our offices, access is transferred if necessary. The employee requests access transfer from their direct manager via JSM. If the employee is managing their MBG group, they can submit the request independently.
10
HR informs the receiving office about the employee’s arrival and confirms the availability of a workspace.
Me on a business trip in Cyprus
Business Trip
Expenses
and
Reimbursement
Main rule — the sending office pays the business trip expenses.
Receiving per diem at the host office is possible if agreed in advance between the sending and receiving offices.
Disbursement is handled by People Partners, office managers, or senior office staff either at the sending or receiving office. Contact information for those responsible can be requested from HR (Victoria Sedash).
From a financial reporting perspective, it is recommended to receive per diem after the trip if issued by the sending office.
Reimbursement of transport and representation expenses can be requested together with per diem after the trip.
Reimbursable expenses include taxi rides to/from the airport and representation expenses
subject to manager approval.
All reimbursements require supporting documents: payment receipts, travel tickets, invoices. No reimbursement is made without proper documentation.
The traveling employee sends supporting documents and reimbursement requests directly to the senior office staff, office manager, or People Partner in their office.
Expenses are charged to the project account where the traveling employee works.
Business trip expenses are charged to the account of the office that issued the funds.
For questions about billing or payments, contact the office manager, People Partner, or finance specialist at the sending office.
Informing
Sending
and
Receiving
Offices
Responsible HR informs the receiving office about the traveling employee, providing their details, trip dates, and the need to organize a workspace.
The receiving office organizes a workspace if needed and provides access to the office for the traveling employee.
How to get information about upcoming events/exhibitions
Data on events and exhibitions the Company participates in can be obtained through HR.
